docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric is selling its remaining stake in Genworth Financial, a life and mortgage insurer, for about $2.8 billion as it leaves the insurance industry to focus on faster-growing markets. About 71 million Genworth Class A shares, valued at $2.3 billion yesterday, will be sold to investors, General Electric said. G.E. will also sell 15 million Class B shares to Genworth at the same price.

headline.main: G.E. Selling $2.8 Billion Stake in Insurer

docs.snippet: General Electric is selling its remaining stake in Genworth Financial, a life and mortgage insurer, for about $2.8 billion as it leaves the insurance industry to focus on faster-growing markets.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Anti-abortion activists in South Dakota claim to be concerned about the ''800 children aborted'' in that state each year, and the State Legislature agrees. Apparently, their concern stops at birth. According to the Children's Defense Fund, more than 27,000 children live in poverty in South Dakota; 18,000 have no health insurance; and two-thirds of fourth graders perform below grade level in math and reading.

headline.main: The Abortion Fight In South Dakota

docs.abstract: Lori Keys Pender letter, prompted by Feb 23 article on South Dakota's ban on most abortions, says legislation is needed to improve lives of children already living in state

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, when Debora Spar, a political economist, began researching ''The Baby Business: How Money, Science and Politics Drive the Commerce of Conception,'' some of her colleagues at Harvard Business School wondered why she had picked a book topic as ''soft'' as the fertility industry. Dr. Spar, a professor of business administration and an associate dean at the business school, disagreed, contending this $3-billion-dollar-a-year sector of the medical economy was ripe for research.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Debora Spar; An Economist Examines The Business Of Fertility

docs.abstract: Interview with political economist Debora Spar discusses her recent book The Baby Business: How Money, Science and Politics Drive the Commerce of Conception; Spar says that new technologies along with changing social norms have made this area of huge growth potential; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Debora Spar became convinced that reproductive technology is a market  with supply, demand and price coming together in a transaction.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cambie Surgery Center, Canada's most prominent private hospital, may be considered a rogue enterprise. Accepting money from patients for operations they would otherwise receive free of charge in a public hospital is technically prohibited in this country, even in cases where patients would wait months or even years before receiving treatment.

headline.main: Canada's Private Clinics Surge as Public System Falters

docs.snippet: Private insurance companies are about to find a gold mine.

docs.lead_paragraph: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi will block the last year of a three-year contract with Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to provide prescription drug coverage to 1.1 million state workers, Mr. Hevesi's office said yesterday. The contract would be worth $1.6 billion in 2008 to Empire, now a subsidiary of WellPoint. The comptroller's office said that Empire, formerly a nonprofit insurer, was given an unfair advantage in the bidding process by being allowed to change its bid three times. The company will be allowed to provide drug coverage through the end of 2007 to avoid disruptions in worker benefits, but the contract will be re-bid for 2008. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Insurance Contract Canceled

docs.abstract: New York State Comptroller Alan G Hevesi will block final year of three-year contract with Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to provide state workers with prescription drug coverage; says Empire was given unfair advantage in bidding process; contract will be re-bid for 2008 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leaders gather this week at a luxury seaside resort here, they will once again be on the defensive, a situation made worse by the split the labor federation suffered last year. Wages for the nation's workers failed to keep up with inflation last year, and unions in the beleaguered automobile, steel and airline industries are battling management's efforts to cut pay and benefits.

headline.main: Labor Leaders to Convene, Faced With Uphill Battles

docs.snippet: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is emphasizing positives at its gathering this week, even though real wages have fallen, recruitment is difficult and the federation suffered a split last year.

keywords.value: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF LABOR-CONGRESS OF INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATIONS

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Sunnis Return to Talks; Sectarian Violence Ebbs The main Sunni Arab political bloc has decided to return to suspended talks over the formation of a new government, a step that could help defuse the sectarian violence and tensions that soared last week and pushed Iraq toward all-out civil war. A1 The Army has decided to reimburse a Halliburton subsidiary for nearly all of its costs on a disputed $2.41 billion no-bid contract to deliver fuel and repair oil equipment in Iraq, even though the Pentagon's own auditors identified more than $250 million in charges as potentially excessive or unjustified. A1 Germany Aided U.S. in Iraq War Two German intelligence agents in Baghdad obtained a copy of Saddam Hussein's plan to defend the Iraqi capital, which a German official passed on to American commanders a month before the invasion. A1 Prisoners Riot in Afghan Jail Up to 5 prisoners were killed and 31 wounded when the inmates in Afghanistan's main high-security prison, among them people accused of being members of the Taliban and Al Qaeda, rioted and seized control of one cellblock. A5 Genocide Probe in Mexico A secret report prepared by a special prosecutor's office says the Mexican military carried out a ''genocide plan'' of kidnapping, torturing and killing hundreds of suspected subversives in the southern state of Guerrero during the so-called dirty war, from the late 1960's to the early 1980's. A3 Europe Counsels Montenegro The European Union's chief foreign policy envoy, Javier Solana, urged Montenegro's independence movement to accept proposals intended to shape a referendum on the future of the small Balkan republic, which is planning to hold a vote in mid-May that could lead to its becoming an independent state. A4 Israel Discounts Abbas The Israeli foreign minister said Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, was ''no longer relevant'' in a Palestinian government soon to be led by the militant Islamic group Hamas. A7 NATIONAL A10-16 Avoiding Institution Life, Elderly Opt for Commune A group of elderly Californians are starting a new chapter in their lives in Davis, Calif., as residents of Glacier Circle, the country's first cooperative housing development for the elderly: a community they planned and designed themselves, right down to its purple gutters. A1 New Form of Computer Hacking In some countries, past forms of computer hacking have been eclipsed by an even more virulent form of electronic con: the use of simple keylogging software that can infect computers, silently copy the keystrokes of their users and send that information to cybercriminals. A1 Labor Leaders Gather The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leaders will gather in San Diego and will once again be on the defensive, a situation made worse by the split the labor federation suffered last year. Wages for the nation's workers failed to keep up with inflation, while unions in the automobile, steel and airline industries are battling management's efforts to cut wages and benefits. A10 Concern About National Guard Governors of both parties complained that Bush administration policies were stripping the National Guard of equipment and personnel needed to respond to hurricanes, floods, tornadoes, forest fires and other emergencies. Tens of thousands of National Guard members have been sent to Iraq. A10 Impending Rail Fee for States After failing in a three-year effort to hand over Amtrak's Washington-to-Boston tracks to a new federal-state consortium, the Bush administration is seeking tens of millions of dollars in extra payments from the states for use of the tracks by commuter railroads serving the route. But the states are complaining that they already have contracts that specify what they should pay. A12 Investigation of Port Deal The Dubai company seeking to take over some operations at six American ports formally asked the Bush administration to conduct a deeper investigation into security concerns surrounding the deal. The request will leave President Bush in the politically delicate position of having to approve or disapprove the takeover. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Fund-Raising SlowsFor Ground Zero Memorial Two years after the designs for a memorial at the World Trade Center were unveiled with great fanfare, the nonprofit group charged with raising $500 million to pay for it is far from its goal and has announced no significant contributions for the last three months. B1 Apartment Clear of Anthrax Laboratory tests have found no traces of anthrax in an apartment in Brooklyn where a man worked on unprocessed animal hides obtained from Vado Diomande, the man who contracted inhalation anthrax this month while making drums from the hides. B2 FASHION B8 SPORTSMONDAY D1-9 Sweden Wins Hockey Gold Thanks to a last-minute save by Henrik Lundqvist, a goalie who plays for the Rangers in the N.H.L., Sweden defeated Finland, 3-2, in the gold medal hockey game that was the final event of the 2006 Winter Olympics. D1 ARTS E1-8 Dungeons & Dragons Online An online version of the role-playing classic Dungeons & Dragons is set for release after more than three years of development. Gary Gygax and Dave Arneson, who created the original together over thirty years ago, have both lent their voices to the new project. E1 New Time Slot for Trump Donald Trump's reality show, ''The Apprentice,'' is scheduled to premiere its fifth edition in a new time slot tonight on NBC. Trump's well-publicized feud with Martha Stewart has helped raise awareness of the show's return. E1 New Look at 'The Nightmare' Henry Fuseli's painting, ''The Nightmare,'' is drawing crowds as the centerpiece of ''Gothic Nightmares: Fuseli, Blake, and the Romantic Imagination,'' which continues at Tate Britain in London through May 1. The painting first attracted attention in 1782. E3 OBITUARIES B6-7 Kenneth McCabe A police detective who became a quiet legend among crime fighters by spying on and testifying against mobsters, he was 59. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Cellphone Entertainment The News Corporation has created a mobile entertainment store called Mobizzo and a production studio to focus exclusively on developing cellphone entertainment in much the same way that 20th Century Fox creates movies and television. C1 The CBS Corporation is expected to announce a subscription service that sends news and entertainment alerts, including video clips, to mobile phones. The service is part of a broad new strategy to sell wireless media products directly to consumers. C1 Wal-Mart and Health Insurance Wal-Mart's chief executive, H. Lee Scott Jr., under mounting pressure to increase spending on employee health insurance, urged the nation's governors not to pass legislation that burdens the company. He pledged to work with the governors to move its workers off state Medicaid rolls. C2 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Crossroads in the national parks; danger signs in Nigeria; Dickensian democracy; debt and taxes. Columns: Bob Herbert and Paul Krugman. Autos D9 Bridge E4 Crossword E6 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E8 Weather D10

docs.lead_paragraph: With Wal-Mart Stores under mounting pressure to spend more on employee health insurance, the company's chief executive on Sunday urged the nation's governors not to pass legislation that would burden the giant retailer, and pledged to work with the governors to move workers off state Medicaid rolls. The executive, H. Lee Scott Jr., said that state bills aimed at improving Wal-Mart's benefits ''may score short-term political points, but they won't solve America's health care challenges.''

headline.main: Wal-Mart Chief Makes Plea to States on Health Care Costs

docs.snippet: With Wal-Mart under pressure to spend more on employee health insurance, H. Lee Scott Jr. urged governors not to pass legislation that would burden the giant retailer.

docs.lead_paragraph: They are unlikely revolutionaries. Bearing walkers and canes, a veritable Merck Manual of ailments among them, the 12 old friends -- average age 80 -- looked as though they should have been sitting down to a game of Scrabble, not pioneering a new kind of commune. Opting for old age on their own terms, they were starting a new chapter in their lives as residents of Glacier Circle, the country's first self-planned housing development for the elderly -- a community they had conceived and designed themselves, right down to its purple gutters.

headline.main: Growing Old Together, in New Kind of Commune

docs.snippet: Opting for old age on their terms, 12 friends in California created the country's first self-planned development for the elderly.
